Fig. 1 shows that the mutation of Lys38 to arginine totally abolished lactate transport by MCT1 expressed in oocytes.
Fig. 1 shows that the mutation of Lys38 to arginine totally abolished lactate transport by MCT1 expressed in oocytes.
Neither of these mutations prevented expression of MCT1 at the plasma membrane.

annotation.text: However, replacement of these three lysine residues with glutamines caused a reduction in reversible inhibition while abolishing irreversible inhibition as predicted from the double mutants of Fig.
In Fig. 3A we show that mutation of Lys38, Lys45, or Lys282 to glutamine gave a considerable reduction in DIDS-mediated cross-linking of MCT1 to embigin,
but the K38Q/K45Q, K38Q/K282Q and K45Q/282Q double mutants almost totally abolished cross-linking
Only with the hextuple mutant K38R/K45R/K282R/K284R/K290R/K413R was cross-linking totally prevented.
Thus the K38R/K45R/K282R/284R/K413R mutant still shows significant, although reduced, cross-linking, whereas the K38R/K45R/K282R/K284R/K290R/K413R mutant does not (Fig. 3C).
but the K38Q/K45Q, K38Q/K282Q and K45Q/282Q double mutants almost totally abolished cross-linking
Only with the hextuple mutant K38R/K45R/K282R/K284R/K290R/K413R was cross-linking totally prevented.

However, when we mutated either Lys160 or Lys164 to glutamine DIDS-mediated cross-linking was reduced with the greatest effect observed with K164Q, whereas the K160Q/K164Q double mutant showed no detectable cross-linking (Fig. 6B).
Lysine residues 160 and 164 of embigin are involved in DIDS-mediated cross-linking to MCT1.
The data of Fig. 6B also demonstrate that we were able to abolish DIDS-mediated cross-linking of MCT1 to embigin by mutating cysteines at position 180 and 182 of embigin to alanine.

annotation.text: This is confirmed by the observation that both the K45Q/K282Q and K282Q/K413Q mutants show no irreversible inhibition, whereas the K45Q/K413Q mutant retains reduced irreversible inhibition (Fig. 2B).

annotation.text: An unexpected experimental finding was that both the K45Q/K282Q/K284Q and K282Q/K284Q/K413Q triple mutants showed some irreversible inhibition by DIDS (Fig. 3C), whereas neither the K45Q/K282Q nor the K282Q/K413Q double mutant did (Fig. 3B).

An unexpected experimental finding was that both the K45Q/K282Q/K284Q and K282Q/K284Q/K413Q triple mutants showed some irreversible inhibition by DIDS (Fig. 3C), whereas neither the K45Q/K282Q nor the K282Q/K413Q double mutant did (Fig. 3B).
However, cross-linking is not totally abolished in the K38Q mutants,

Lys290 appears to be the residue that is covalently modified by the isothiocyanate group of DIDS under these conditions because mutation of lysine residues 38, 45, 282, 284, and 413 to arginines maintained some cross-linking, but this was prevented when Lys290 was also mutated to arginine.

we employed lysine and cysteine mutants of embigin (Fig. 6). These data implicate Lys160 and Lys164 in the cross-linking and suggest that the Ig-like V domain of embigin nearest to the membrane may bend over toward the extracellular surface of MCT1.
Furthermore, we found that C180A/C182A embigin also failed to cross-link with MCT1 consistent with disruption of the disulfide bridge in the V domain,
